The Axe Will Fall
The great guillotine "Finals" rears once more above
the flaxen locks of the Homewood ex-hedonists; although
an aura of knowledge will cloud the campus, although
the undergraduate body will panic in palsied time to
Veritas Vos Liberabit, within three weeks many a head
will roll. Not long ago we rubbed our inflamed eyeballs
and asked why do approximately 25% of the undergraduates flunk at least one course each semester? We concluded that possibly the reading period is too short, that
possibly too many people have too many exams in too
few days, and that possibly something can be done
about it.
In a random sampling involving approximately onetwelfth of the undergraduate body, 40 freshmen, 30
sophomores, 30 juniors (no seniors, as many of their
exams are cancelled) ; 51 Arts and Sciences majors, 19
Business majors, 30 engineers) we compiled the following,data: Forty-eight percent of the students will have at
least two finals in one day; two-thirds, of these students
will have at least one more examination either one day
prior or later than the date of the two exams. Sixtyseven percent of those polled will take at least one test
in each of three consecutive days.
Hopkins now has a final examination period of only
six days, whereas until a few years ago the examinations
spanned ten days. We asked Registrar Irene Davis about
this. A shorter school- year was wanted, she stated, "and
someone had to get squeezed." We can readily understand why the undergraduate got it in the neck. It seems
to be in keeping with the Hopkins attitude.
We randomly picked out six catalogues of other
colleges. These are the facts: Union College, eleven days
of finals; Middlebury College, ten days; Columbia, ten
days; Haverford, twelve days; Dartmouth, nine days;
Harvard, nineteen days (plus• a nineteen day reading
period).
We leave the above facts for the readers to chew
for one week; next, week, more pertinent problems and
some solutions from the editors.

It's About Time ...
One of the most pleasant but sorely lacking contributions of the Student Council are the assemblies, held
Fridays at 10:00 a.m. Three years ago, Shriver Hall assemblies were initiated with notable success by the very humorous and
talented Al Capp. Unfortunately, nothing on a similar
plane of enjoyability has been presented since.
This year the Student Council has shown little initiative in scheduling assemblies. Dr. Eisenhower's address
to the students was indeed an excellent contribution to
the Hopkins community, but an obvious need to everyone.
The two Bell Telephone movies were placed in the lap of
the Council; the Council had little to do in procuring them.
We suggest that the new Council begin now to work
up a sched4le of assemblies for next year and if finances
are the stumbling-block, that efforts be made to obtain
the funds either through the SAC or from other sources.
By working now, the Council may be able to take
advantage of the traveling schedules of talent suitable for
assemblies. For example, concerts might be arranged if
George Shearing should come to town again. Friday
morning should not conflict with his club engagements and
since he is in town, the cost would be low. The same thing
is true of dance bands, and classical artists. Speakers
such as Al Capp, Walt Kelly, an,d Ogden Nash could be also
scheduled when in this area.

Electrons are removed from

positive particles (in this case,

tube.
The huge positive charge on
the dome, forces the particles
down the high-vacuum tube in a
rapidly-moving stream. A series
of electrodes, forty-seven in all,
is placed atound the tube, each
electrode down carrying a slightly lower positive charge than
the one above it. The .electrodes
give the particles added velocity

Long before Columbus landed at San Salvador in
1492, the Iroquois were playing the old game of "baggataway." Renamed lacrosse by the French settlers of
Canada, because the curved, netted stick resembled a
Go
bishop's crozier, the game was taken up by the white Seven Down, One To
men about 1840. It is the oldest sport in 'America.
As most of you are well aware, Johns Hopkins is
Planning on sending a lacrosse team to England in the
summer of 1958, having received an invitation from the
English Lacrosse Union.
"After hearing reports that they would be interested
in having us, knowing of our reputation in American
lacrosse, we wrote and were invited to come over," said
Athletic Director Marshall S. Turner, Jr.
According to Turner, the trip is to include eight or
nine games, probably a game or two with the combined
Oxford-Cambridge group, going then to Manchester in
northern England, where the best lacrosse is played, and
then return to London.
"They suggested that we take a break in the trip
and see some of Scotland while we are there. After the
games are over, the boys plan to do some touring on their
Own. The cost of meals and lodging during the trip is
included in the $15,000," added Turner.
The traveling party of twenty-five will include Coach
Bob Scott, Trainer Jimmy Benson, and Turner.
Although only a small group is making the trip, they
are going as representatives of the entire university. The
Boosters Club is currently conducting a fund-raising
campaign among the student body, giving the students
the opportunity to do their share toward sending the
team to England. We wish to express our support of
this project and urge everyone to contribute to the drive.

The Axe Will Fall
The great guillotine "Finals" rears once more above
the flaxen locks of the Homewood ex-hedonists; although
an aura of knowledge will cloud the campus, although
the undergraduate body will panic in palsied time to
Veritas Vos Liberabit, within three weeks many a head
will roll. Not long ago we rubbed our inflamed eyeballs
and asked why do approximately 25% of the undergraduates flunk at least one course each semester? We concluded that possibly the reading period is too short, that
possibly too many people have too many exams in too
few days, and that possibly something can be done
about it.
In a random sampling involving approximately onetwelfth of the undergraduate body, 40 freshmen, 30
sophomores, 30 juniors (no seniors, as many of their
exams are cancelled) ; 51 Arts and Sciences majors, 19
Business majors, 30 engineers) we compiled the following,data: Forty-eight percent of the students will have at
least two finals in one day; two-thirds, of these students
will have at least one more examination either one day
prior or later than the date of the two exams. Sixtyseven percent of those polled will take at least one test
in each of three consecutive days.
Hopkins now has a final examination period of only
six days, whereas until a few years ago the examinations
spanned ten days. We asked Registrar Irene Davis about
this. A shorter school- year was wanted, she stated, "and
someone had to get squeezed." We can readily understand why the undergraduate got it in the neck. It seems
to be in keeping with the Hopkins attitude.
We randomly picked out six catalogues of other
colleges. These are the facts: Union College, eleven days
of finals; Middlebury College, ten days; Columbia, ten
days; Haverford, twelve days; Dartmouth, nine days;
Harvard, nineteen days (plus• a nineteen day reading
period).
We leave the above facts for the readers to chew
for one week; next, week, more pertinent problems and
some solutions from the editors.

Bob Scott, Trainer Jimmy Benson, and Turner.
Although only a small group is making the trip, they
are going as representatives of the entire university. The
Boosters Club is currently conducting a fund-raising
campaign among the student body, giving the students
the opportunity to do their share toward sending the
team to England. We wish to express our support of
this project and urge everyone to contribute to the drive.

Jazz Concert Conduct
Receives Approval
Dr. G. Wilson .Shaffer, Dean
of the Homewood Schools, expressed satisfaction this week at
the way the Jazz Concert was
conducted.
He said, "Boys really are not
drinking any more today than
when I was in college." And
added, "The times when we have
had a critical situation are almost always developed by outsiders." Dean Shaffer noted,
"Fraternity boys need to get
more publicity about the decent
things they do."
Os Steinwald, Jr., president of
the Junior Class, also said he
was well satisfied by the conduct
at the Jazz- Concert. "I thought
decorum was kept at a proper
level, and I thought the students handled themselves very
well."
He stated, "The difficulties
encountered last year as to
rowdyness and trash being left
on the campus were met and
effectively dealt with this year.
The cleanup crew did an excellent and speedy job."

Tours

Steinwald further said,"As the
Jazz Concert was conducted so
well this year, I see no reason
not to continue it in the future.
This year's concert certainly will
serve as a fine example."
The cost of the Jazz Concert
was principally met by the Class
of 1958, the sponsors, but the
Classes of 1957, 1959, 1960, the
Boosters Club, the H-Club and
most of the social fraternities
contributed.

Ron Nagler, Mike Lukens, Malcolm Kitt, Boland McCamy, and
Howie Richter were elected to
next year's 'Y' Cabinet at a recent election.
The new Cabinet met this
morning at ten to elect a president and secretary.
Also, John Cooper was reelected as editor and Jim Anderson as business manager of the

Cooper and Anderson again received the posts they held last
year because of the "competent
job" they did on the recent book.
It is reported that they are getting an "earlier start" on next.
year's handbook, which is expected to appear in August.
